page.title: 02WATER TREATMENT PLANT
page.content: The pumping and treatment plant, built in 1898, on the outskirts of Goudhurst supplies water to Benenden, Cranbrook, part of Kilndown, Marden, Rolvenden and Staplehurst. Originally water came from 4 bore holes, 25 metres deep. 6 more bore holes 100 metres deep were bored in 1950 and 2 more in 1962. The plant is manned for 24 hours a day in shifts, so alarm signals from more modern pumping stations are monitored here. Water comes up the bore holes over aeration towers to get rid of iron. Lime takes out other oxides. A gravity filter takes out particles to a settling tank, the sludge being dumped in the old railway cutting. Chlorine, to kill bacteria is removed with sulphur dioxide. It is then filtered and pumped to our taps.
